channel.title: Blog on Digital Accessibility
channel.description: Practical advice on digital accessibility for frontend developers, QA testers and designers. Here you'll learn about methods of creating accessible and user-friendly interfaces, standards, assistive technologies and laws.

item.title: Role attribute with multiple values
item.description: In what cases may be necessary to set multiple values for a role attribute, and how browsers and screen readers deal with this.

item.title: How to avoid harming users with epilepsy and vestibular impairment
item.description: What if the user gets motion sickness because of a website? What if he or she has an epileptic seizure? Let's look at what interfaces for users with epilepsy and vestibular impairment should look like.

item.title: Everything you need to know about ARIA Live Regions
item.description: If you have a dynamically changing part of a page and you're thinking about making it accessible, there may be a legitimate question about how to do it. In the past, assistive technologies (including screen readers) didn't know how to handle them properly. Now the problem of accessibility of dynamically changing page content can be solved with ARIA.

item.title: CSS media feature to improve accessibility
item.description: What custom settings come and how to take them into account in web interfaces. You will learn about media features that track animation settings, contrast, transparency, inversion, colour scheme and forced colour mode.

item.title: Understanding skip link
item.description: How to skip large navigation with skip link, who needs it and what are the approaches to implementing skip content pattern.
